text.p: The following is a direct contribution from commodity statistician F.O. Licht in Ratzeburg, Germany. Please address any queries to Helmut Ahlfeld on +00 49 4541 88920.

White sugar futures in London ended mixed in quiet dealings. August added 70 cents to close at $321.00 per tonne, while October lost 20 cents to close at $310.40 per tonne. There was no fresh news to influence prices. The markets in the UK and the United States are closed on Monday. Raw sugar futures in New York finished firmer in near session highs, but activity remained thin ahead of the holiday weekend. Many players started their memorial day weekend early, which left volume slim. Thai raw sugar premiums were slightly higher as the market expected more buying by China on the back of strong whites premiums. With the white sugar premium at almost $100 per tonne, China is expected to speed up its tolling business especially as Thailand has no more white sugar left in stock. Thailand sold out of white sugar earlier in the season because of strong demand, mostly from Indonesia. July added 5 points to close at 11.11 cents/lb, while October closed 4 points higher at 10.91 cents/lb.

FRANCE - The French sugar market Intervention Board FIRS estimates sugar consumption in March 1997 at 150,000 tonnes, white value, slightly below the 156,000 tonnes attained in March 1996 and also down on the five-year average of 169,000 tonnes. Cumulative consumption in the first half of 1996/97 reached 954,200 tonnes, 40,000 tonnes up on the 1995/96 result and 11,000 tonnes higher than the five-year average.

DENMARK - Sugar exports in February 1997 amounted to 8,306 tonnes, raw value, down from 13,651 tonnes in February 1996. This brought cumulative exports in October/February 1996/97 up to 68,430 tonnes against 68,238 tonnes in 1995/96. Total exports in 1995/96 reached 173,004 tonnes compared to 199,559 tonnes in 1994/95. Major countries of destination in October/February 1996/97 were Norway with 38,076 tonnes whites against 48,725 tonnes, Libya with 15,400 tonnes against nil and Iceland with 4,321 tonnes against 3,700 tonnes.

POLAND - Sugar imports in January 1997 reached 10,944 tonnes, raw value, up from 1,031 tonnes in January 1996. This brought cumulative imports in September/January 1996/97 up to 41,463 tonnes, down from 66,645 tonnes in the like period the previous year. Total imports in 1995/96 reached 85,306 tonnes against 100,248 tonnes in 1994/95. Major countries of origin in September/January 1996/97 were Germany with 13,104 tonnes whites against 7,975 tonnes, the Czech Republic with 10,991 tonnes against nil and France with 3,829 tonnes against 8,015 tonnes. Sugar exports in January 1997 reached 8,072 tonnes against negligible amounts in the same month the previous year. This brought cumulative exports in September/January 1996/97 up to 173,162 tonnes against 2,025 tonnes in 1995/96. Total exports in 1995/96 reached 4,440 tonnes against 14,828 tonnes in 1994/95. Major countries of destination in 1996/97 were Syria with 28,189 tonnes raws against nil, Germany with 23,358 tonnes whites against nil, Algeria with 23,27

The first contingent of sugar (16,574 tonnes of French white sugar) bought by Iraq under its oil-for-food deal with the United Nations, reached the country. Iraq began in April distributing food to its citizens under the oil deal, which lets Baghdad sell $2 bln worth of oil over six months to meet urgent needs of Iraqis hit by UN trade sanctions since Iraq's 1990 invasion of Kuwait.
